tags: i can't believe i'm posting something written for the first time in literal years
summary: for keeps (in which snufkin has nothing to lose)
title: for keeps (in which snufkin has nothing to lose)
body:
Every year, the sure sign that Snufkin had to leave was not the chill on the wind or the frost fluttering through the air, but it was the sign of something warm turned cold all the same. It was the way Moomintroll’s face would scrunch up, the tell-tale twitch of his nose that meant all the tears he’d succeeded in holding back up to that point were flooding forward. That, he thinks bitterly when his back is turned, is the worst flood Moominvalley has to suffer every year. 

The tears are his own fault, really. Moomintroll’s, not his. Didn’t he heed his warning years ago when the comet still streaked its terrible trail above them? Nature always found a way to punish those who wanted to have things in one way or another. Indifferent waves sweep away rivers and houses all the same, and it’s the houses’ faults for wanting to have one place all to themselves. Fathers too — Moomintroll should know that better than anyone, and yet Snufkin can’t understand why he still wants so much. Snufkin feels grumpy all of a sudden.

He should be crying, that Moomintroll, he finds himself thinking, though he immediately feels bad and wants to bury the idea right where he found it.

If he won’t learn from my telling him, then certainly words won’t help him, the horrible thought continues, as loud and dreadful as distant thunder.

“It’s not the way of things to want too much,” Snufkin says aloud now, his boots crunching along the snowy path out of Moominvalley. He pulled his mouth-organ from his rucksack and gave it’s mirrored surface a wipe with his sleeve.

“Keeping anything comes with a price, and if you ask me it’s always far too high,” he continues to no one in particular, as no one is there to listen. “Tears are expensive. A Snufkin who owns only what is free never cries over anything because he has nothing to lose, so that must be the right way of things.”

An image of Moomin on the bridge flashes through his mind and he doesn’t welcome it at all. His face is still scrunched in that horrible way, his soft mouth frowning in a way that didn’t look right on the happy-go-lucky creature.

“Pah!” he says out loud again, to the sky and the wood and whoever’s listening that could maybe get the image of his friend to leave him. (He does not want to have to ask.) “What did I say? Go through life without wanting anything and you’ll have nothing to-!“

A drip hitting the snow in front of him stops the young vagabond in his tracks. He thinks of Moomin again. The memory that comes up is against his will, yet great golden relief rushes through him as the image of his friend on the bridge is replaced by that same soft mouth smiling in the summer sunset.

Two more drips hit the snow in quick succession, burrowing little holes in the frosty surface as they fall. Snufkin looks up to the branches, expecting to find the newborn icicle that’s making such a fuss somewhere among them. Instead, he feels an unfamiliar wetness roll down his cheeks and towards his ears, though the crisp forest wind whips them away before they can reach them.

Snufkin reaches up to touch the tears as they roll down his face. He hasn’t cried in a long time. He also hasn’t taken a breath in the last minute, and when he does, it comes out shaking and shuddering like a leaf.

“Lose,” he sobs out, finishing his sentence with a sniffle. He pockets his mouth-organ again and uses his now free hands to scrub furiously at his eyes, which only prompts another wave of tears. When he opens his eyes again, the trail before him is blurry. He walks on anyway, and the crunch of the snow under his boots is the same as before.

“Nothing to lose,” he repeats with the voice that he knows will eventually stop shaking, just as it does every year.
body_abstract: Every year, the sure sign that Snufkin had to leave was not the chill on the wind or the frost fluttering through the air, but it was the sign of something warm turned cold all the same. It was the way Moomintroll’s face would scrunch up, the tell-tale twitch of his nose that meant all the tears he’d succeeded in holding back up to that point were flooding forward. That, he thinks bitterly when his back is turned, is the worst flood Moominvalley has to suffer every year.

summary: Well, that was shitty episode. Moominpappa was pretty bad dad, really self-centered - like how that’s possible?  And they made...
body:
Well, that was shitty episode. Moominpappa was pretty bad dad, really self-centered - like how that’s possible?

And they made me hate Little My again. What the actual fuck? That is unforgivable! Fuck you, Moominvalley, fuck you.

Sniff and Snufkin was the best thing in that episode. And Moominmamma, also.

summary: Way back in 2017, when I first started working on the new series of Moomin Valley, I was asked to produce a new map for the...
caption: Way back in 2017, when I first started working on the new series of Moomin Valley, I was asked to produce a new map for the series. The map went through a few iterations before landing on a style that paid homage to Tove Jansson’s iconic style without directly ripping it off.  Moomin Valley is now far more vast and has so many more locations but I’m still quite chuffed with how this came out. I love doing these sorts of tasks for productions but being in preproduction means that many never see the light of day. This ended up being one of the rewards to those who helped fund the series so its nice to know its out there somewhere.

This ended up being one of the rewards to those who helped fund the series so its nice to know its out there somewhere.

tags: this is a long ramble but i thought about it a lot
title: Snufkin being supportive
body:
in episode 5: “The golden tail,” (kultainen häntä)  Moominpappa puts on a play that tells a story of his younger days. Snufkin is seen sitting through every rehearsal, and the actual premiere of the play as well. 

in the beginning of the episode he offers a complimentt, saying that it’s starting to go well. This implies that he’s been at previous rehearsals as well. He’s honestly trying to encourage them here, but his line is followed by Moominpappa yelling that the play is a terrible fiasco. Seeing how Moominpappa is acting as a director, it’s no wonder Snufkin would want to slip in a positive word. 

at the day of the dress rehearsal Moomin is nowhere to be seen, and Moominpappa is frustrated. 

we get a closeup of Snufkin giving a look to the situation. He’s most likely wondering about Moomin’s whereabouts as well, but honestly.. with the way Moominpappa is acting it wouldn’t be a surprise if Moomin didn’t show up at all. 

ALSO what’s interesting to me is that Snufkin is seen holding the boat Moomin got in the previous episode. The boat was spinning counterclockwise when placed on water, and Snufkin wondered if it was a sign. Moomin reasoned that it was probably just because the wind was turning. 

Even so, Snufkin picked up the boat and took it with him. That’s interesting. Seeing it make an appearance again makes me wonder if it really does mean something in the end. It may not, but who knows. 

 the day of the premiere rolls around, and Snufkin is sitting pretty close and center. Moominpappa was constantly telling Moomin to get to the center of the stage, so I find it nice that Snufkin is sitting in his direct line of sight. The whole situation has been extremely stressful for Moomin, so to have his best friend in his constant view should be comforting. 

we see Snufkin pay great attention to the play, reacting in unison with the rest of the audience. He even laughed a little bit, which is quite rare for him. It’s really meaningful to see him reacting so openly, especially when it’s Moomin up there on the stage, most likely watching for his reactions. The only thing an audience can really do to offer support to the actors without making a sound, is to be expressive. 

then everything goes wrong and we can see how bad Moomin feels before the curtains close and the intermission begins. 

Moominmamma turns to Snufkin, and the two share a look, before Snufkin gets up and goes to find Moomin. 

we see Moomin gazing sadly at the script. he’s holding his golden tail, but let’s it drop and sighs. Snufkin finds him, and says the tail could always be cut off, but that could disappoint others. Moomin goes to the door to see Sniff selling fake golden tails to the excited audience. People liked the play. 

Moomin remains frustrated and states he’s not his father, and that he’s just himself. Snufkin gazes gently at Moomin, and leaves after stating happy endings are pleasant. Following this conversation, Moomin is able to come up with a solution to the problem at hand. 

Deep down this episode heavily revolved around Moomin finding confidence in himself. He was pressured to play a part he didn’t feel confident in. He got a  self-esteem boost from his golden tail, but in the end it didn’t change anything. He still couldn’t play the part of his father. Snufkin didn’t at any point tell Moomin what he should do, or what he thought of the play. He allowed Moomin to find the solution on his own, but it’s clear that Snufkin’s words and presence helped Moomin a lot. 

Moomin becomes the director of the play, and the role of his father is played by Moominpappa. The play is a success, and the audience claps in captivation. Snufkin has moved to a boat on the side, and he claps and cheers, telling Moomin that he did a good job. 

Snufkin is the kind of character that  has no need for the opinions of others, and therefore has no need to impress anyone. When you don’t care about compliments or support, it can be extremely difficult to give them out to others. It’s painfully clear that Moomin is trying so hard to do a good job, and make his friends and family proud.

 Snufkin’s way of offering his support, is to simply be there for Moomin. Everyone knows he could be out there doing anything whenever. He has no obligation to sit through every rehearsal, but he does. He chose to be there. Clapping and giving out a compliment is huge, and definitely means a lot to Moomin. 

So far the new show has done a good job of showing Snufkin’s considerate side towards Moomin, and I’m excited to see them explore it more.

reblog.comment:
in episode 5: “The golden tail,” (kultainen häntä)  Moominpappa puts on a play that tells a story of his younger days. Snufkin is seen sitting through every rehearsal, and the actual premiere of the play as well. 

in the beginning of the episode he offers a complimentt, saying that it’s starting to go well. This implies that he’s been at previous rehearsals as well. He’s honestly trying to encourage them here, but his line is followed by Moominpappa yelling that the play is a terrible fiasco. Seeing how Moominpappa is acting as a director, it’s no wonder Snufkin would want to slip in a positive word. 

at the day of the dress rehearsal Moomin is nowhere to be seen, and Moominpappa is frustrated. 

we get a closeup of Snufkin giving a look to the situation. He’s most likely wondering about Moomin’s whereabouts as well, but honestly.. with the way Moominpappa is acting it wouldn’t be a surprise if Moomin didn’t show up at all. 

ALSO what’s interesting to me is that Snufkin is seen holding the boat Moomin got in the previous episode. The boat was spinning counterclockwise when placed on water, and Snufkin wondered if it was a sign. Moomin reasoned that it was probably just because the wind was turning. 

Even so, Snufkin picked up the boat and took it with him. That’s interesting. Seeing it make an appearance again makes me wonder if it really does mean something in the end. It may not, but who knows. 

 the day of the premiere rolls around, and Snufkin is sitting pretty close and center. Moominpappa was constantly telling Moomin to get to the center of the stage, so I find it nice that Snufkin is sitting in his direct line of sight. The whole situation has been extremely stressful for Moomin, so to have his best friend in his constant view should be comforting. 

we see Snufkin pay great attention to the play, reacting in unison with the rest of the audience. He even laughed a little bit, which is quite rare for him. It’s really meaningful to see him reacting so openly, especially when it’s Moomin up there on the stage, most likely watching for his reactions. The only thing an audience can really do to offer support to the actors without making a sound, is to be expressive. 

then everything goes wrong and we can see how bad Moomin feels before the curtains close and the intermission begins. 

Moominmamma turns to Snufkin, and the two share a look, before Snufkin gets up and goes to find Moomin. 

we see Moomin gazing sadly at the script. he’s holding his golden tail, but let’s it drop and sighs. Snufkin finds him, and says the tail could always be cut off, but that could disappoint others. Moomin goes to the door to see Sniff selling fake golden tails to the excited audience. People liked the play. 

Moomin remains frustrated and states he’s not his father, and that he’s just himself. Snufkin gazes gently at Moomin, and leaves after stating happy endings are pleasant. Following this conversation, Moomin is able to come up with a solution to the problem at hand. 

Deep down this episode heavily revolved around Moomin finding confidence in himself. He was pressured to play a part he didn’t feel confident in. He got a  self-esteem boost from his golden tail, but in the end it didn’t change anything. He still couldn’t play the part of his father. Snufkin didn’t at any point tell Moomin what he should do, or what he thought of the play. He allowed Moomin to find the solution on his own, but it’s clear that Snufkin’s words and presence helped Moomin a lot. 

Moomin becomes the director of the play, and the role of his father is played by Moominpappa. The play is a success, and the audience claps in captivation. Snufkin has moved to a boat on the side, and he claps and cheers, telling Moomin that he did a good job. 

Snufkin is the kind of character that  has no need for the opinions of others, and therefore has no need to impress anyone. When you don’t care about compliments or support, it can be extremely difficult to give them out to others. It’s painfully clear that Moomin is trying so hard to do a good job, and make his friends and family proud.

 Snufkin’s way of offering his support, is to simply be there for Moomin. Everyone knows he could be out there doing anything whenever. He has no obligation to sit through every rehearsal, but he does. He chose to be there. Clapping and giving out a compliment is huge, and definitely means a lot to Moomin. 

So far the new show has done a good job of showing Snufkin’s considerate side towards Moomin, and I’m excited to see them explore it more.

summary: as a finnish person who grew up with moomin it is SO WEIRD to see Tumblr Fandom Posts about it w/ like shipping, cute fan art...
body:
as a finnish person who grew up with moomin it is SO WEIRD to see Tumblr Fandom Posts about it w/ like shipping, cute fan art etc… before y’all found it making Moomin Content was up to us finnish millenials & we only made youtube poops and shitty memes about getting wasted

(”3 beers and pappa is fighting again”)

(”can’t even think with this hangover”)

and thingumy and bob enjoying a nice summer day as you do up here in the north :-)

(”3 beers and pappa is fighting again”)
